you can see we we have you know just sort of walk through the pipeline you have an instruction fetch unit which
is fetching out of the eye cache it can be fetching either microcode or
arm instructions if it's in the arm instruction mode those instructions are being fed into a
hardware decoder which does a very simple one to two instruction translation
of those instructions into a naive native microcode implementation of
those instructions and then and then the results are fed
down into the scheduler and executed on the seven wide machine so obviously if you're just taking in
one to two arm instructions at a time and playing them on this seven wide machine you're probably idle most of the time
and so uh that's where dynamic code optimization comes in it's how we uh it's it's the technology
we use to sort of figure out how to use this large wide execution resource that we
have so some of the features of denver that may or may not be familiar to all of you
we have a skewed pipeline i'll talk a little bit more about that in in the next slide we have

idea that's been kicking around for a while in in-order machines i think we've made
it work and made it yield performance uh and we have transactional memory and

at the iso level uh we do it under the covers and use that to accelerate
our uh accelerate code that runs on the processor
so i talked a little bit about pipeline sku um this is kind of a i just wanted to
briefly talk about it because it's something that surprised some people who've come into our project from other
other places a traditional critique of wide in-order machines is that it's
really hard to schedule onto them particularly if you have limited scheduling regions
you'll tend to have a bunch of loads up front you'll have to wait a while in order to
be able to use the results from those loads and control flow can become sort of
problematic in terms of the scheduling um what we do in denver is we have these
wide superscalar ops we call them or wide super scalar we call them bundles
which are a collection of ops that come in you can think of them as entering the
machine at the same time but depending upon the kind of operation they are they execute at different times
in the processor pipeline and we have bypassing between the different units that allows them to be
the results to be used later in in sort of useful ways so uh what i've diagrammed here is sort of
what i think of as the big big deal bypasses from loads you can bypass
to the arithmetic units from the arithmetic units you can bypass back out to stores
or you can bypass predicate results into our branch unit so what that leads to is bundles that
look a little bit like this i've tried to use some color coding to help out with this
but what you can see in this is we have a load where the result is being used to feed
an ad and then the result of the ad is being fed back out to a store uh
we're taking a com we're doing a compare on the value that we loaded and then we're
branching based on the result of that compare so what you can see is it's not
immediately obvious until you start looking at larger windows of instructions but if you're taking
arm operations and trying to map them into wide bundles that allows you to have a
really dense you know to to really densely pack those sort of all the way through despite
having quite a bit of control flow transfer back and forth

is is usually reasonably good at doing um
